beats.label: HOOK + PROMISE
beats.narration: Should you race The GRiT Adventure? I rated 328 gravel races on 14 dimensions. The GRiT Adventure scored 47 out of 100. Solid tier. Here's what that actually means for your season.
beats.text_on_screen: Should You Race The GRiT Adventure?
beats.editing_note: STATE THE PREMISE IN 8 SECONDS. Clear value prop: 'I rated 328 races. Here's where this one lands.' This is the 8-second decision window. Viewers who stay past 15s are 58% more likely to finish.
beats.psych_mechanism: Curiosity gap (specific) + IKEA effect (viewer predicts the tier before reveal).

beats.label: THE COURSE
beats.narration: The GRiT Adventure. Snoqualmie Pass, WA. 65 mi. Washington Cascades mountain gravel.
beats.text_on_screen: The GRiT Adventure | Snoqualmie Pass, WA | 65 mi
beats.editing_note: Let the course breathe. Show the route map, then cut to terrain-specific B-roll. This is the SETUP phase — grounding the viewer before the data analysis. Pacing: 25-40 sec cuts.

beats.label: THE SCORES — Top 8
beats.narration: Time to break down the scorecard. Length. 3 out of 5. Long enough to matter. Short enough to recover. Technicality. 3 out of 5. The course bites if you stop paying attention. Elevation. 3 out of 5. Proper climbing. You'll earn your descents. 5500 feet over 65 miles averages 85 feet per mile, which is climbing. Adventure. 3 out of 5. This race takes you somewhere different. The first descent "turn right into the woods" leads to "mostly doubletrack, singletrack, and FUN" through forest terrain. Experience. 3 out of 5. You'll remember this one. Mostly fondly. Starting at Crystal Springs Sno-Park and mixing "asphalt, dirt/gravel roads, with some double track sections" delivers Adventure Gravel. Value. 3 out of 5. Fair value. You get what you pay for. No entry fee data available, but camping along I-90 keeps costs reasonable and you get Cascade wilderness suffering. Expenses. 3 out of 5. Standard gravel race budget. Logistics. 2 out of 5. Functional. Not impressive. Packet pickup from 7:00-8:30am for a 9:00am start leaves little buffer time, especially with day-of registration closing at 8:30am.
beats.editing_note: PROGRESSIVE RHYTHM: start tight (15-20 sec per dimension), slow down for the most interesting scores (30-40 sec). Each score: number appears, brief pause, explanation. Avatar reacts to extreme scores (5/5 = chef_kiss, 1/5 = facepalm). RE-ENGAGEMENT at 3:00 mark: insert a surprising score reveal or a meme reaction to break the pattern.

meme_insert.suggested_clip: avatar reaction to most extreme score

beats.label: THE SCORES — Also Scored
beats.narration: And the rest of the scorecard. Climate. 2 out of 5. Mostly pleasant. Check the forecast anyway. Altitude. 2 out of 5. Negligible altitude effect. Race Quality. 2 out of 5. Basic but functional. Gets the job done. Community. 2 out of 5. Riders acknowledge each other. Barely. Prestige. 1 out of 5. Nobody at the coffee shop will recognize this name. Field Depth. 1 out of 5. Small field. You might podium by showing up.
beats.editing_note: FAST PACING — 7 seconds per dimension. Quick-fire energy change from the deep analysis above. This is a PATTERN INTERRUPT through pacing shift.

beats.label: VERDICT
beats.narration: Verdict: Washington Cascades Adventure. If you're local to WA. yes, it's solid. If you're traveling. skip it.
